The Cabinet had under consideration thefollowing documents dealing with unemployment,the general e&economic problem and the organisation for dealing with unemployment relief schemes.A Memorandum by the Lord Privy Seal(Paper No. CP. 21(30)).A letter dated 23rd January 1930 from theChancellor of the Duchy of Lancastercovering a Memorandum (Paper No. CP.31(30)) .A Memorandum by the First Commissioner ofWorks (Paper No. CP.32(30)).A Letter from the Parliamentary Under-Secretaryof State for Scotland (Paper No. CP. 33(30)).The Cabinet were reminded that owing to the absenceof colleagues at former meetings it had not been possible-to have the discussion on Unemployment Policy earlier,though the subject had been on the Agenda from thebeginning of January.THE LORD PRIVY SEAL made a full statement of thepresent position and made special reference to the unsatisfactory condition of the basic industries, to theincrease in the weekly figures of unemployment, and .to the opposition he was encountering in the House ofCommons from all Parties in his efforts to hasten the passage of those portions of Bills, promoted byLocal Authorities, which would increase employment.Mr. Thomas compared the schemes put in force by thepresent Government with those of the late Government, andoutlined the course he proposed to take in a debate on the subject in the House of Commons that afternoon.He added that he had experienced every possible assistance at the hands of the Civil Service in. hisattempt to grapple with the problem. In the course of the discussion which followedattention was drawn to the probability that thesituation would become worse before it became better,to the immediate effects of rationalisation in adding to unemployment, and to difficulties arising out ofthe fiscal policies of the Dominions. Emphasis was laid on the importance of distinguishing between the varying repercussions of financial expenditure onrelief, on schemes offering immediate productiveresults, and on long range schemes of reconstructionthe resultant economies of which would not be visiblefor some time, possibly not for two'years or more.It was generally agreed that policies of additionalunproductive relief should be strongly discouraged.The suggestion was made that it might become necessaryto introduce legislation which would enable thecentral government to override the obstacles whichplebiscites In some localities were offering in opposition to the decision of Councils to promoteschemes, valuable in themselves and helpful indealing with the present emergency.Cabinet 23 Reference was also made to the alleged failure(29)Conclusion 3. to secure satisfactory co-operation in theadministrative arrangements for dealing with unemployment.The Cabinet agreed:-(a) To authorise the Lord Privy Seal tomake a statement in the House OfCommons that afternoon on the linesof his report to the Cabinet, includingthe censure of those members of all parties," who were blocking Bills anddelaying schemes which would affordemployment. (b) To appoint a Committee consisting of:-The Chancellor of the Exchequer(In the Chair')The Minister of Health,The Minister of Labour,The Secretary of State for War,Mr. R.B.Howorth (Secretary)to consider, in consultation withThe Lord Privy Seal,The First Commissioner of Works,The Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster,The Parliamentary Under-Secretary ofState for Scotland.the Unemployment situation in the-lightof the latest figures, and in thisconnection to have regard to the Memorandumof Sir oswald Moseley and the letters ofMr. Larrrbury, and Mr. Thomas Johnston.(C.I. 31, 32, 33 of 1930)._ry- o- SlOMILG ADVISORYffclL.2, THE PRIME MINISTER reported to theCabinet the result'of his consideration of therious Ref-ce: Cabinet 3(30) membership of the proposed Economic Advisory Councilelusion 6 andendix) . and of its staff.Members of council.6O7.(i) THE PRIME MINISTER submitted the following-names as suitable members of the Council:Sir Arthur Balfour.Sir John Cadman.Sir Andrew Duncan.Sir William McLintock.Sir Josiah Stamp.The Hon.
